content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Carlos Duran: I was born in the Dominican Republic, but I came to the United States when I was just a baby. My parents brought me to the Bronx when I was around two years old, and I've been here ever since. Growing up in the Bronx wasn't easy. My father passed away when I was still a teenager, and my mother worked long hours to keep our heads above water. We lived in a small apartment on Elmwood Avenue, and I remember walking to school every day with my backpack on my shoulder, trying to focus on my studies even though life was tough. I always knew I had to work hard to make something of myself. I got my high school diploma, and then I went on to college, eventually earning a graduate degree. I've been working full time for the past ten years, and while I'm not wealthy, I've built a stable life for myself. I still speak Spanish at home with my family, and I'm proud of my roots. I'm a Catholic, and my faith has always been a source of strength for me. I'm not really political, but I do believe in doing what's right and helping others when I can.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Carlos Duran: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was around 18, right after my father passed away. That hit us really hard. My mom was working two jobs, and I was trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life. I had a friend who was going to community college and talked me into applying. But I also had another friend who was working at a local store and said I should just get a job and start saving money. I was torn because I knew education was the way out, but I also didn't want to leave my mom alone to struggle. In the end, I decided to go to community college part-time while working nights at a bodega. It wasn't easy—sleeping in the day, studying at night, trying to keep up with classes and work. But that experience taught me discipline and responsibility. I eventually transferred to a four-year university, got my degree, and then went on to graduate school. That decision to keep pushing through, even when it felt impossible, shaped who I am today. I wouldn't be where I am without that moment of choice.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Carlos Duran: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I remember sitting at the kitchen table with my mom, looking at the two paths in front of me—education or work. I didn't want to leave her, but I also knew that if I didn't take the chance, I'd be stuck in the same cycle she was in. I told myself that if I worked hard enough, I could make a better life for both of us. It wasn't just about me; it was about giving my mom a future where she wouldn't have to work herself to the bone. I remember praying that night, asking God to guide me, and the next morning, I called the community college and signed up. That moment was the start of something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Carlos Duran: Absolutely, I think someone or something could have helped. My mom was working so many hours, she didn't have time to think about things like scholarships or financial aid. I remember seeing flyers at the library about free tutoring and counseling for students from low-income families, but I didn't know how to apply for any of it. If someone had reached out to me, even just to talk, it might have made all the difference. I think organizations that support first-generation students or immigrants could have been a big help. I didn't have anyone to guide me through the process, and that made it harder. But I also know that not everyone has that kind of support, so I try to help others when I can, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Carlos Duran: I don't have a partner or children right now. My life has been pretty focused on work and trying to build a stable future for myself and my mom. She's still living with me in that same apartment on Elmwood Avenue, and I make sure she's taken care of. We have a routine—she helps me with some of the cooking, and I take her to the doctor's appointments when needed. I've always felt responsible for her, especially after my father passed away. I know I'm not the most romantic guy, but I think about what's important. I've had a few relationships over the years, but nothing serious. I guess I've been too focused on my goals and making sure we're both okay. I don't mind being single; I have my family, my faith, and my work. That's enough for me.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my life from the beginning made me realize how far I've come, even if I'm not where I thought I'd be at this point. The crossroads I described when I was 18 was a defining moment, and it's interesting to look back and see how that decision shaped everything after. I didn't have much support back then, and I think about how things might have been different if someone had reached out to me. Now, with my mom still living with me, I feel a deep sense of responsibility to take care of her, and I'm grateful for the life I've built. It's not perfect, but it's stable, and that's something I can be proud of.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Carlos Duran: My immediate family, besides my mom, includes my two sisters. One lives in Santo Domingo, and the other is in Queens. We don't talk as much as I'd like, but I know they care. My older sister, Maria, she's a nurse, and she always sends me care packages with food and medicine when she can. She's the one who encouraged me to go back to school after my father passed. My younger sister, Ana, she's still in high school, and I try to check in on her whenever I can. It's hard because we're all so busy, but I feel like I owe it to them to be there. I guess family is complicated, but I'm grateful for them in my own way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Carlos Duran: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends from my neighborhood who I've known since high school. We used to hang out a lot, play basketball, and talk about our dreams. Some of them still work at the bodega or other local stores, while others have moved on to different things. One of them, Luis, actually went back to school and became a teacher. He's the one who always reminds me to never stop learning. I don't see them as much as I'd like, but when we do get together, it's like no time has passed. I also have a few coworkers who I consider friends—people who understand the long hours and the struggles of making ends meet. They're the kind of people who will lend you an ear or a hand when you need it. I think friendship is important, even if I don't always make time for it. I guess I'm just grateful for the people who stick around, even when life gets tough.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Carlos Duran: I live in the same neighborhood I've always known—the Bronx. It's a place that's seen a lot of changes over the years, but some things never really change. Elmwood Avenue is still lined with small businesses, bodegas, and family-owned shops. It's a tight-knit community, even if it's not always easy. There are good people here, people who know each other's names and look out for one another. I've seen a lot of my neighbors struggle, just like I did, but there's a resilience here that's hard to explain. The streets can be rough, and there are challenges—poverty, crime, the constant hustle—but there's also a sense of pride. People work hard, they raise their kids, and they keep going. I still walk to the corner store sometimes, just like I did when I was a kid, and I see the same faces. It's home, even if it's not perfect. I wouldn't trade it for anything because it's where I built my life, where I learned to fight for what I wanted, and where I still have my mom. The Bronx may not be the fanciest place, but it's real, and it's where I belong.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Carlos Duran: I think I feel safe here, but it's not the kind of safety you see in the movies or read about in magazines. It's more like a quiet safety—knowing the people around you, even if they're struggling, have your back in some way. I've been mugged once, and that was scary, but I've never felt like I was in danger for long. The streets can be rough, but I've learned to be cautious, to watch my surroundings, and to trust my instincts. I know my neighbors, and they know me. If something happens, someone will look out for me. It's not perfect, but it's real. I think that's the kind of safety that matters most—being part of a community that, even in tough times, doesn't let you fall too far.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Carlos Duran: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like life itself. There are days when I feel proud of where I am—owning my own small apartment, being able to provide for my mom, and having a stable job. But there are also days when I look around and wonder if I could have done more, if I could have made things easier for her. The Bronx has given me a lot, but it's also tested me in ways I never expected. I've seen friends fall into bad situations, people I cared about get lost in the struggle. But I've also seen the good—the way people come together during tough times, the way a neighbor will lend you a hand without asking for anything in return. It's not always easy, but I've learned to find strength in the little things. The smell of coffee from the corner bodega, the sound of kids playing in the park, the way my mom smiles when she sees me coming home. Those are the things that make it all worth it.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood have shaped who I am today. Talking about my mom, my sisters, and the people I grew up with reminded me of the strength it takes to hold on to family, even when life is tough. It also made me think about how much my neighborhood has been a part of my journey—both the struggles and the support I've received from the people around me. I've always known the Bronx as home, but hearing myself talk about it again made me realize how much it has given me, even in its roughness. I'm proud of the life I've built here, and I know I wouldn't be where I am without the people who have stood by me, even when I didn't have much to offer in return.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Carlos Duran: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are still variations depending on work and my mom's schedule. I start my day early, usually around 5:30 or 6 in the morning, because I have to be at work by 7. I work at a local warehouse, so it's physically demanding, but I've gotten used to it. After work, I come home, make sure my mom has something to eat, and then I try to do some chores or run errands. On weekdays, I usually have some time in the evening to study or catch up on work-related tasks, especially if I'm taking any courses online. On weekends, I like to take my mom to the park or to church, and sometimes we go to a local diner for breakfast. I also try to meet up with some of my old friends from high school if I can. Life isn't always easy, but I find comfort in the routine and the little moments that keep me going.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Carlos Duran: I work at a local warehouse, mostly loading and unloading shipments. It's a physically demanding job, but it pays the bills and gives me a sense of purpose. I work from around 7 in the morning until 3 in the afternoon, five days a week. The hours are long, but I've gotten used to them over the years. What I like about the job is that it's straightforward—there's no room for nonsense, and everyone knows their role. I've been there for almost seven years now, and I've built some good relationships with the other workers. We all come from different backgrounds, but we share the same struggles. Some of them are immigrants like me, others are locals who grew up in the Bronx. We talk about everything—work, family, the neighborhood. It's not glamorous, but it's honest work, and I respect that. I know I could be doing something else, something with more prestige, but this job keeps me stable and allows me to take care of my mom. That's what matters most to me.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Carlos Duran: Outside of work and taking care of my mom, I also try to stay active in my community. I volunteer at the local church a few times a month, helping with food drives and organizing events for the kids in the neighborhood. It's not much, but it feels good to give back, especially since I know what it's like to struggle. I also take some online courses in my spare time—mostly things like business management or leadership skills. I don't know if I'll ever use them, but I like to keep learning. It keeps my mind sharp and reminds me that I'm still growing, even if it's not always in the way I expected. And every Sunday, no matter how tired I am, I make sure to go to Mass with my mom. It's our time to pray, to reflect, and to remember where we came from. Those are the things that keep me grounded.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Carlos Duran: Well, lately, I've started waking up a little earlier than usual, maybe 5:00 or 5:30, just to get a few extra minutes of quiet time before the day starts. I've been trying to read more—mostly books about personal development or stories from other immigrants who made it through tough times. It helps me feel connected to people who've been through similar struggles. I also started going to the gym a couple of times a week, even if it's just for an hour. It's hard to find the motivation sometimes, but I know it's good for my health and my mind. My mom noticed and started joining me for walks in the park a few times a week. It's nice to see her moving around more, even if it's just a short walk. I guess I'm just trying to find little ways to improve my life, even if it's not a huge change. It's not about being perfect—it's about taking care of myself so I can keep taking care of her.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Carlos Duran: I don't have children of my own, but if I did, I imagine their days would be pretty similar to how I lived when I was growing up. They'd wake up early, maybe around 6 or 7, have breakfast, and then head off to school. After school, they'd probably come home, do their homework, and maybe play with friends or join a community program. I know a lot of kids in the neighborhood take part in after-school activities at the community center—things like sports, art classes, or tutoring. I think it's important for kids to have structure and support, especially in a place like the Bronx where there are so many challenges. If I had children, I'd want them to have those opportunities, to feel safe, and to know that education is their way out. I'd also make sure they knew their roots, that they were proud of where they came from, and that they never stopped believing in themselves.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood have shaped who I am today. Talking about my mom, my sisters, and the people I grew up with reminded me of the strength it takes to hold on to family, even when life is tough. It also made me think about how much my neighborhood has been a part of my journey—both the struggles and the support I've received from the people around me. I've always known the Bronx as home, but hearing myself talk about it again made me realize how much it has given me, even in its roughness. I'm proud of the life I've built here, and I know I wouldn't be where I am without the people who have stood by me, even when I didn't have much to offer in return.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Carlos Duran: My health has been up and down over the years, like everything else in my life. I've always been pretty active, working at the warehouse and walking around the neighborhood, but the job takes a toll on my body. I've got some back pain from lifting heavy boxes, and my knees aren't as strong as they used to be. I try to take it easy when I can, but sometimes I push through because I know I have to be there for my mom. I don't go to the doctor as much as I should—I know that sounds bad, but it's not like I have the time or the money to spare. I take some over-the-counter pain relievers when it gets too bad, and I've been trying to eat better, even if it's just more vegetables and less fried food. My mom worries about me, and I don't want to add to her stress. I know I should take better care of myself, but I guess I'm just used to pushing through. I hope I can keep going like this for a while longer, though. I owe it to both of us.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Carlos Duran: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that my mom is counting on me. That gives me a reason to push through, to take those extra steps, even when my body is telling me to stop. But what makes it hard is the reality of my situation—money is tight, and sometimes I have to choose between buying medicine or paying for groceries. I also struggle with time. Between work, taking care of my mom, and trying to keep up with my studies, there's not much left for self-care. I know I should eat better, exercise more, and go to the doctor, but it's easy to put those things on the back burner when life feels like it's moving so fast. I guess the truth is, I don't always prioritize my health the way I should, but I'm trying. I want to be here for my mom, and I want to keep going, even if it's not always easy.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Carlos Duran: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some pretty persistent back pain that's gotten worse, especially after lifting heavy boxes at work. I finally went to the doctor a few months ago, and they said it's probably from years of strain and maybe some early signs of arthritis. It's not anything too serious, but it's uncomfortable and limits what I can do. I've been using a heating pad and taking some pain medication, but I know I need to do more—like maybe see a physical therapist or get a proper diagnosis. The thing is, I don't want to miss work, and I don't want to burden my mom with more stress. I've also been having some trouble sleeping because of the pain, which makes me feel more tired and less focused at work. It's a cycle, really. I know I should take better care of myself, but it's hard when you're used to pushing through everything. Still, I'm trying to be more mindful, even if it's slow progress.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Carlos Duran: It's definitely affected me, especially with the back pain. Some days, I feel like I can barely get through my shift at the warehouse. I've had to take it slower, which means I'm not lifting as much as I used to, and that worries me because I know I need to keep working to support us. I've also noticed that when I'm in pain, I'm not as patient with my mom, and that's something I hate about it. I don't want her to feel like I'm frustrated with her, but sometimes I get tired and snap at her for things that aren't even her fault. It's hard to explain, but I feel like the pain is taking a piece of me, and I don't know how to fix it. I guess what I'm saying is, health problems don't just affect your body—they affect your mind, your relationships, and your ability to keep going. I'm trying to stay strong, but I know I need to do more for myself before I can be there for anyone else.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Carlos Duran: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just keeping my head above water. The back pain has been a constant companion, and it's made me more aware of how much I push myself without really taking a step back. I've been trying to be more present with my mom, even when I'm tired or in pain. We've had some good conversations, and I've realized how much I value her presence in my life. I've also been trying to be more consistent with my health, like going to the gym a few times a week and eating better, even if it's just small changes. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm trying to do better for both of us. Life hasn't been easy, but I've learned to find strength in the little things—the way my mom smiles when I come home, the way the neighborhood feels like home even when it's rough. I'm not where I thought I'd be at this point, but I'm still moving forward, one day at a time.

Going through the recent interview questions made me think a lot about how my health has been holding me back, even as I try to keep moving forward. It's not just the physical pain from years of hard work—it's the way it affects my mood, my patience, and even my ability to be there for my mom. I know I should take better care of myself, but it's hard when money is tight and time is even tighter. I've started making small changes, like waking up earlier and going to the gym, but it's not always easy. Still, I keep going because I know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to take care of anyone else. I'm trying to be more mindful, even if it's slow progress, and I hope that one day I can look back and say I did what I could for my health and for my family.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Carlos Duran: I think I've dealt with some sadness and worry, especially with the pain and the stress of making sure everything stays okay for my mom. There are days when I feel like I'm just going through the motions, like I'm not really living, just surviving. I don't know if it's depression exactly, but there are times when I feel heavy, like the weight of everything is just too much. I've tried to push it aside, to focus on work and taking care of my mom, but sometimes it creeps in and makes me feel like I'm not enough. I don't talk about it much, not even with my friends or my sisters, because I don't want them to worry. But I know I can't carry it all on my own. I've started going to the church more, talking to the priest, and it helps. It's not a cure, but it gives me something to hold on to. I guess what I'm saying is, I've had my moments, but I'm still here, still trying to do what's right, and that has to count for something.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Carlos Duran: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and quiet moments of strength. My mom has been dealing with her own health issues lately—her knees are giving her trouble, and she's been going to the doctor more often. It's hard to see her in pain because I know how much she's sacrificed for me over the years. She still tries to help out around the house, but I've started taking on more of the chores so she can rest. My sisters, they're both doing well in their own ways. Maria is still working as a nurse, and she's been busy with her job, but she always makes time to call or send me a message. Ana is in high school now, and she's been applying to colleges. I'm proud of her, even if I don't see her as much as I'd like. I know she's going through her own struggles, just like I did when I was her age. It's not always easy being part of a family that's had so much hardship, but I think we've all learned to lean on each other. Even in the tough times, we keep going because we know we're not alone.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Carlos Duran: For me, religion has always been a source of strength, especially during the hardest times. Being Catholic is more than just going to Mass on Sundays—it's about the faith that got me through my father's passing, the struggles of growing up in the Bronx, and the moments when I felt like giving up. I believe in God, and I believe that He has a plan for everyone, even when we can't see it. My mom and I go to church every Sunday, and it's our time to pray, to reflect, and to remember where we came from. I've always felt that faith gives you something to hold on to when life feels too heavy. It doesn't erase the pain, but it helps you carry it. I know some people don't believe in religion, and that's okay. But for me, it's been a lifeline, a way to find peace in the chaos, and a reminder that I'm not alone in this journey.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Carlos Duran: To be honest, I don't use social media much. I know people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through posts and videos, but I never really got into it. I think it's more of a distraction than anything else. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with my sisters and some old friends from high school. I'll check it maybe once a week, see what they're up to, and sometimes I'll post a picture of my mom and me at church or something like that. But I don't follow a lot of people, and I don't spend much time on it. I guess I just prefer face-to-face conversations or talking on the phone. There's something real about that, you know? You can't fake a smile over a phone call, and you can't hide behind a screen. I know I'm missing out on a lot, but I don't feel like I need it. My life is right here, in the Bronx, with my mom, my faith, and the people I know. That's enough for me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Carlos Duran: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really used social media for support, emotional or otherwise. I know people use it to share their struggles, to find communities, or even to raise money for things, but I've never felt the need to do that. I've always believed that the people I care about are right here, in my life, not behind a screen. If I'm going through something, I talk to my mom, or I go to church, or I call one of my sisters. I trust them, and they've always been there for me. I guess I just don't see the point in putting my problems out there for strangers to see. It's not that I don't want support—it's just that I've always found it in the people I already know. Maybe that's old-fashioned, but it's worked for me so far.

Going through the questions about my health and how it's affected my life has made me realize how much I've been pushing through without really taking a step back. I've always thought of myself as strong, someone who can handle anything life throws at me, but the truth is, I've been holding on by a thread for a long time. The back pain isn't just a physical burden—it's taken a toll on my mood, my patience, and even the way I treat my mom. I hate that I've been so quiet about it, not wanting to add to her stress or make her worry. But I can't keep pretending everything's fine. I need to take better care of myself, not just for me, but for her too. I've started making small changes, like waking up earlier and going to the gym, but it's not always easy. Still, I keep going because I know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to take care of anyone else. I'm trying to be more mindful, even if it's slow progress, and I hope that one day I can look back and say I did what I could for my health and for my family.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Carlos Duran: Honestly, my stress levels have been pretty much the same as they've always been—constant, but I've learned to manage it in my own way. I used to worry a lot more about the future, about whether I was doing enough for my mom or if I'd ever be able to get out of the cycle we've been in for so long. But lately, I've been trying to focus more on the present. I've started talking to the priest more during Mass, and he's been a good reminder that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, as long as I keep moving forward. I also find that taking those little steps—like going to the gym, eating better, or even just sitting down with my mom and having a real conversation—helps me feel more grounded. I know I'm not perfect, and I still have days where I feel like I'm barely holding on, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself. I guess what I'm saying is, I'm not sure if I've found the perfect way to cope, but I'm learning that it's not about being stress-free—it's about not letting it break me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Carlos Duran: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and my mom's medical bills. Rent is the biggest chunk—around $1,200 a month for the apartment we've been in since I was a kid. Groceries come next, especially since my mom doesn't eat much these days and I try to make sure she gets the right things. I also have to pay for her doctor visits and prescriptions, which can add up. Then there's the cost of the pain medication I've been using for my back, and I still have to buy gas for the car, even though I don't use it much anymore. I work full time, but my paycheck barely covers all of that. I try to save a little bit each month, just in case something comes up, but it's tight. I know I could be doing better, but I'm just trying to keep us afloat. It's not easy, but I've learned to live within my means and make the most of what I have.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Carlos Duran: Honestly, the amount we spend each month is pretty much the same, give or take a few dollars here and there. I usually spend around $1,200 on rent, which is the same as last month. Groceries are about $400, and that includes what I buy for us both. My mom doesn't eat much these days, but I still try to make sure she gets the right meals, even if it means buying more vegetables and less meat. Then there's her medical expenses—doctor visits, prescriptions, and the occasional physical therapy session. That adds up to maybe $300 or so. I also have to pay for my pain medication, which is another $100 or so. And then there's the car payment, even though I don't use it much anymore. It's about $150 a month. So altogether, that's around $2,150, and I make just over $2,500 a month after taxes. It's tight, but I manage. I try to save whatever I can, even if it's just a few dollars here and there, just in case something comes up. It's not much, but it's something.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Carlos Duran: We rent our home. It's the same apartment on Elmwood Avenue that I've lived in since I was a kid. It's not much—just a small two-bedroom unit, but it's been our home for so long that it feels like part of us. The rent is pretty high for the neighborhood, but we've always managed to keep up with the payments. I know it's not the most stable situation, but it's familiar, and I don't want to uproot my mom just for the sake of moving somewhere else. We've had our share of repairs over the years—leaky pipes, old appliances, things like that—but we've always fixed them as we go. It's not perfect, but it's what we have, and I'm grateful for that. I've thought about buying a place, but with my income and my mom's medical expenses, it's just not realistic right now. For now, renting is what keeps us afloat.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Carlos Duran: Over the past year, my bills have gone up and down depending on the season and what's going on with my mom's health. In the winter, heating costs get a little higher, and I have to use more electricity for the lights and the heater. I also noticed that my mom's medical bills have been a bit more expensive lately—she had to go to the doctor more often, and her prescriptions got more expensive after her insurance changed. Then there's the holidays, like Christmas and Easter, when I try to buy her some small gifts or take her out for a meal. Those things add up, even if it's just a few extra dollars here and there. On the other hand, some months are easier—like when I don't have to pay for any repairs or when I can save a little more by buying groceries in bulk. It's not always the same, but I've learned to adjust. I know I can't control everything, but I try to plan ahead as much as I can so we don't get caught off guard.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my faith have been my anchors through the struggles I've faced. Talking about my mom's health and how I've been trying to take care of her reminded me of how much I've grown as a person, even if I'm not always proud of the way I've handled everything. It also made me think about how I've relied on my faith to get through the hard times, and how important it is to have that sense of purpose, even when life feels overwhelming. I've always believed that religion is more than just going to church—it's about finding strength in the belief that I'm not alone, that there's something bigger than myself. And even though I don't use social media much, I know that the support I've received from my family and my community has been just as real and just as powerful. I may not have all the answers, but I know that I'm doing the best I can, and that has to count for something.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Carlos Duran: I try to save whenever I can, even if it's just a little bit each month. I have a small savings account, and I put whatever I can spare in there—maybe $50 or $100 a month, depending on how things go. It's not much, but it gives me some peace of mind, just in case something comes up. I know I could be saving more, but with the way things are, I have to be careful with every dollar. I also keep some cash at home, just in case the bank is closed or I need it for something unexpected. It's not the most organized way, but it's what works for me. I used to think saving was something for people who had more money, but I've learned that even small amounts can add up over time. I just hope that one day, I can save enough to do something bigger—not just for me, but for my mom too.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Carlos Duran: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day than anything else. I know life can change in an instant, and I want to be prepared just in case something happens to me or to my mom. Last year, I started setting aside a little more each month, not just for emergencies, but also for things like her future medical needs or even something as simple as a trip to the doctor if the insurance doesn't cover it fully. I also try to save for small things that make life a little easier—like buying a new pair of shoes or replacing the old microwave that's been acting up. It's not about big dreams or buying a house, it's about being ready for the little things that can add up. I know I could be saving more, but I want to make sure we're both taken care of, even if it's just a few dollars at a time.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Carlos Duran: My occupation has always been about hard work and responsibility. I work at a local warehouse, mostly loading and unloading shipments. It's physically demanding, but I've gotten used to it over the years. The most important part of my job is making sure everything is done right—no mistakes, no delays. I take pride in knowing that my work keeps things moving, even if it's just for a few hours a day. What I like most is the sense of purpose it gives me. I know I'm not making a lot of money, but I'm providing for my mom, and that's what matters most. I've been there for almost seven years now, and I've built some good relationships with the other workers. We all come from different backgrounds, but we share the same struggles. Some of them are immigrants like me, others are locals who grew up in the Bronx. We talk about everything—work, family, the neighborhood. It's not glamorous, but it's honest work, and I respect that. I know I could be doing something else, something with more prestige, but this job keeps me stable and allows me to take care of my mom. That's what matters most to me.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Carlos Duran: I usually work around 40 hours a week, five days a day, from 7 in the morning until 3 in the afternoon. It's a long shift, but I've gotten used to it. The hours are pretty consistent, though sometimes there are days when we have to stay late if there's a rush or a shipment that needs to be handled right away. I don't mind the schedule too much because it gives me a clear structure—wake up early, work, come home, take care of my mom, and then try to rest or do something for myself. The only thing is, when I'm working those long hours, it's hard to find time for everything else. I know I should be taking better care of my health, but it's easy to let the day slip by when you're just trying to get through your shift. Still, I keep going because I know I have to. This job isn't glamorous, but it's what keeps us afloat, and I'm not about to give that up.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Carlos Duran: No, I haven't had more than one job. I've always focused on doing one thing well—working at the warehouse. It's not the most exciting job, but it's steady, and I've built a routine around it. I used to think about taking on extra shifts or side jobs, especially when money was really tight, but I always ended up turning them down. The truth is, I don't have the energy for it. After a full day of work, I come home and have to take care of my mom, make sure she's okay, and then try to rest. I've tried to do more, but I've learned that pushing myself too hard just leads to burnout. I've seen friends who took on multiple jobs and ended up breaking down—physically and mentally. I don't want that for myself. So I stick to one job, one schedule, and I make it work. It's not much, but it's enough for us.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress and emotional struggles have shaped my daily life, and how I've learned to cope with them in my own way. Talking about my stress levels and how they've remained constant over time reminded me of how I've always carried the weight of responsibility for my mom and our household. It's not easy, but I've found ways to manage it—whether it's through my faith, small changes in my routine, or just being present with the people I care about. I've also realized how important it is to take care of my health, even if it's just in small ways, like going to the gym or eating better. It's not about being perfect—it's about not letting the stress break me. I've also thought a lot about how my family and my faith have been my anchors through all of this. They've given me strength when I didn't have any left, and I'm grateful for that. Even though life hasn't been easy, I know I'm doing the best I can, and that has to count for something.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Carlos Duran: In total, my household made just over $2,500 in the past month after taxes. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics—rent, groceries, my mom's medical bills, and the car payment. I work full time, and that's it. I know I could be making more, but I've never been one for taking risks. This job has kept us stable for years, and I don't want to mess with that. I've thought about going back to school for something else, maybe a management course or something that could lead to a better-paying job, but I don't know if I can afford it right now. I want to make sure we're both taken care of, and I don't want to take on more debt. It's a tight balance, but I've learned to live within my means. I'm not rich, but I'm not struggling either. I just hope that one day, I can do a little better—not for myself, but for my mom, who has always given me everything.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Carlos Duran: I've been at the warehouse for almost seven years now, and it's been a long time since I started. The benefits aren't much—just a few days of paid time off a year, and no health insurance through the job. I've always had to rely on my own savings or my mom's insurance for medical stuff. The company does offer some sort of retirement plan, but I don't know much about it because I've never really looked into it. What I do know is that the job gives me a steady paycheck, and that's what matters most. I've seen other workers leave for better opportunities, but I've always stayed because I know this job keeps us afloat. It's not perfect, but it's honest work, and I respect that. I don't ask for much—just a way to provide for my mom and keep our heads above water. That's been enough for me.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Carlos Duran: My relationships at work are pretty straightforward—no drama, no nonsense. I've been there long enough to know my place, and the other workers respect that. My manager is a no-nonsense guy, always focused on getting the job done. He doesn't play favorites, and he doesn't tolerate slacking off. I've had my share of disagreements with him over the years, especially when I've had to push back because of my mom's health or when I've been in too much pain to work at full capacity. But for the most part, we get along. He knows I'm not one to cause trouble, and I know he's not going to fire me for something minor. As for my coworkers, we all have our own stories, our own struggles. Some of them are immigrants like me, others are locals who've been in the Bronx their whole lives. We talk about everything—work, family, the neighborhood. It's not always easy, but there's a kind of brotherhood there. We look out for each other, even if it's just a nod or a quick word when someone's having a rough day. I don't ask for much from this job, but I do appreciate the people I work with. They're real, they're honest, and they've been there for me when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Carlos Duran: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is both a blessing and a curse. I start at 7 a.m. every day, five days a week, and I usually finish around 3 p.m. The hours are consistent, which helps me plan my day around taking care of my mom and managing my health. But it's not always flexible. If there's a rush or a shipment that needs to be handled, we sometimes have to stay late, and there's not much I can do about it. I've learned to roll with it, but it's not ideal when I have to push through the pain just to meet a deadline. Still, the predictability gives me a sense of control, even if it's not much. I know when I need to be there, and I know when I can come home and be with my mom. That's something I can count on, and in a life that's had so many uncertainties, that's not nothing.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Carlos Duran: Overall, I feel like I'm managing, but it's a tightrope walk every day. I know I'm not rich, and I know I could be doing better, but I also know that I'm doing what I can for my mom and for myself. I've never been one for complaining, but sometimes I wonder if I'm just stuck in this cycle—working hard, barely making ends meet, and never really getting ahead. I want more than this, but I also know that I can't just quit my job or take a risk without knowing I'll be able to take care of her. I've seen people around me make mistakes, take chances, and end up worse off than they were before. I don't want that for us. So I keep going, even if it's slow progress. I'm not proud of everything, but I'm proud of the fact that I haven't given up. I'm still here, still trying, and that has to count for something.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life have shaped my daily struggles and decisions. Talking about my bills and how they fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of how unpredictable life can be, even when you're trying your best to stay on top of things. It also made me think about how my job at the warehouse, while steady, doesn't offer much in the way of benefits or flexibility, which limits my ability to plan for the future. I've always believed that hard work would get me somewhere, but sometimes I wonder if I'm just staying in place, working the same hours, earning the same amount, and barely making it from month to month. Still, I know I can't give up on this life—not for me, and especially not for my mom. I've learned to live within my means, to make the most of what I have, and to find strength in the small things. Even if I'm not where I want to be, I'm still moving forward, one day at a time.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Carlos Duran: Yes, my mom worked for pay for at least a year while I was growing up, and honestly, she worked a lot more than that. She had two jobs most of the time—first, she worked at a local diner in the mornings, and then she went to a cleaning service in the afternoons. I remember her coming home exhausted, sometimes with her hands still cleaning, and she'd just sit on the couch for a while before she could even think about cooking dinner. She never complained, not really. She just did what she had to do to make sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. I was still in high school then, and I remember feeling guilty for not being able to help more, but I didn't know how. She always told me not to worry, that she was used to working hard. But looking back now, I realize how much she sacrificed for me. I think that's why I've always felt responsible for her—because she gave me everything she could, even when she didn't have much to give. I don't know what I would have done without her.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Carlos Duran: My mom's job was cleaning—mostly in people's homes, but she also worked at a diner for a while. She'd start her day early, sometimes before dawn, cleaning floors, washing dishes, and making sure everything was spotless before the customers came in. Then, after that, she'd go to a different job, usually someplace else in the Bronx, where she'd clean offices or apartments. It wasn't easy work, but she did it with pride. She always said that if you clean someone else's home, you have to treat it like it's your own. I remember seeing her come home with her hands sore, her back aching, but she never complained. She just took off her apron, sat down for a minute, and then started cooking dinner. I used to think she was just tired, but now I realize how much strength it took for her to keep going, day after day, without ever asking for much in return. She gave me everything she could, even when she didn't have much to give. That's why I feel like I owe it to her to take care of her now, just like she did for me when I was growing up.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Carlos Duran: My mom worked for different people—mostly private households and small businesses in the Bronx. She didn't have a formal job with a company; she worked as a cleaner for whoever needed her help. Some days, she'd clean for a family with kids and a dog, making sure every corner was spotless. Other days, she'd be in an office, wiping down desks, mopping floors, and organizing papers. She didn't make much, just enough to cover the rent and groceries, but she always made sure we had what we needed. I remember her telling me that she didn't mind the work because it gave her a sense of purpose. She always said, 'If I can make someone's home feel like a home, then I've done my job.' I think that's why she never complained, even when she was exhausted. She gave me everything she could, and I'll never forget that.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Carlos Duran: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here, still taking care of my mom, but maybe with a little more stability—maybe a better job, something that pays a little more and gives me some benefits, like health insurance or paid time off. I don't want to dream too big, because I know it's not easy, but I do want to be able to give her more than just a roof over our heads. I want her to be comfortable, to not have to worry about the next bill or the next doctor's visit. I also hope that I'm healthier, that I've taken better care of myself, and that I'm not constantly in pain. I know I can't change everything overnight, but I want to keep moving forward, even if it's just one step at a time. I hope that I can look back in a few years and say I did the best I could for both of us, and that I didn't give up, even when it felt impossible.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Carlos Duran: What I value the most in my life is family, especially my mom. She's been through so much, and I know I can't change the past, but I want to make sure she doesn't have to struggle anymore. I value the little things too—the way she smiles when I come home, the way she still tries to help out even when she's in pain. I value my faith, because it's been my anchor through everything. And I value the strength it takes to keep going, even when life feels heavy. I don't have a lot, but I have these things, and that's enough for me. I know I'm not perfect, but I try to be the best version of myself for the people I love.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial situation shape my daily life and the choices I make. Talking about my income, my job at the warehouse, and the lack of benefits reminded me of how limited my options are, but also how grateful I am for the stability I have. It also made me think about the relationships I've built at work—the coworkers who understand the struggles, the manager who keeps things running, and the sense of brotherhood that comes from working together through tough times. I know I'm not in a perfect situation, but I've learned to make the most of what I have. I've always believed that hard work gets you somewhere, and even though I'm not where I want to be, I'm still here, still trying, and that has to count for something.

Going through this interview has been like looking back at the whole journey of my life, from the struggles of growing up in the Bronx to the decisions that shaped who I am today. It's amazing how much I've come through, even if I'm not where I thought I'd be. I've always known that my mom's sacrifices and my own hard work have brought me this far, and I'm proud of the life I've built for us. It's not perfect, but it's stable, and that's something I can be grateful for. I've learned so much about myself through this process—about the strength it takes to keep going, the importance of family and faith, and the small victories that make life worth it. I know I still have a long way to go, but I'm not giving up. I'm still here, still trying, and that has to count for something.
